data.name: AdditionalInformation
DescriptionOfExistingSolutionsAndAnalysis
data.value:
Here you should describe what are the devices or therapies on the market; if possible, list some pros and cons of the existing solutions.
Example: list medical, surgical or technical solutions available; define the criteria to choose amongst the have different options. Comment on residual side effects or contraindications that may be improved.
Worked example: congenital club foot is usually treated by braces (mild cases) or surgery. Both solutions require long healing times and frequent specialistic follow up visits.

data.name: DescriptionOfNeeds
data.value:
Here you should describe the clinical need that is the target of your device. Example 1: write the common or technical name of the pathology, describe the main symptoms and if it is acute/chronic. Example 2: write the common or technical name of the handicap, describe if it is innate or caused by incidents or a consequence of a pathology Example 3: describe what is the patient need in terms of cost / improvement of life conditions / improvement of wellbeing
Worked example 1: Down sindrome is a sindrome linked to various conditions, from lowered cognitive functions to increased risk of heart failure
Worked example 2: congenital club foot is a disease of newborn children that impairs the development of the lower limbs
Worked example 3: patients with high body temperature (fever) need to assess their body temperature every 1-4 hours in a quick and reliable manner.

data.name: PatientPopulationStudy
data.value:
Here you should describe how many patients you suppose would need your device, and give description of their state of health and any subgroups.
Example 1: evaluate how many patients are registered for the target pathology in your country/ worldwide and comment any differences.
Worked example 1: neonatal hypothermia affects xxx% of preterm children and xx% of babies at term. This means an estimate of xxx babies per year worldwide.
Example 2: evaluate how the current patient population may evolve over time/ as developing countries increase their access to health services
Worked example 2: Age related dementia affects xxx% population in the USA; similar numbers may be found in Europe, varying from xx% of Italy to xx% of Russia. In developing countries, as the life expectancy is lower, this pathology is found in xx% of population that is xx% of population in the age group 65 and older.

data.name: ProductFunctionality
data.value:
Here you should briefly describe your device and how it works. Describe how your product will meet and solve the clinical need.
Example 1: describe how the device interacts with the human body and why this interaction is beneficial.
Worked example 1: the syringe allows to deliver liquid substances, for example drugs, to the peripheral blood stream of the patient by piercing the vein walls without laceration
Example 2: describe which clinical parameter is measures/ altered/ affected by the device
Worked example 2: the oximeter allows measuring the amount of circulating haemoglobin by evaluation of light absorption.

data.name: ProductPerformance
data.value:
Here you should describe the main working parameters of your device and why they are significant to describe its interaction with the patient.
example 1: describe the time of use, kind of interaction with the human body, forces involved
worked example 1: the haemodialysis machine allows transferring the blood from the patient body to a filter, by plastic tubings. The blood is circulated in low pressure by a peristaltic pump for some hours and continuously recirculated to the patient.
worked example 2: a dental implant is inserted by screwing it in the vital bone; after healing, the dental implant inside the bone is connected to an external abutment that sustains the mechanical forces of mastication
worked example 3: a defibrillator delivers electric energy to the chest of the patient.

data.name: ProductSafety
data.value:
Here you should describe the main risks that your device may pose to the patient, to the users and bystanders and to the general environment. Propose solutions if you are aware of them.
Example 1: evaluate electrical and mechanical safety of the device
Worked example 1: haemodialysis machine is powered by electricity, there is a risk of electrocution of the patient and operator if it is not well insulated. In the same machine, the roller pump may hurt the operator hands if it is touched while it is rotating. Possible solutions include insulating the electrical connections and protecting the moving parts with covers or lids
Example 2: evaluate biological safety of the device
Worked example 2: a needle penetrates the skin of the patient; it must be sterile and made in a material that does not cause irritation or inflammation. The same needle poses a contamination and wound hazard to the nurse after its use. At the state of the art, many metals including steel are known to be compatible with the human body and sterilizable. Means of protecting the tip after use should be provided to the operator.

data.name: ProductUsability
data.value:
Here you should describe who will use the device and if they need special training.
Example 1: define the professional profile of the end user
Worked example 1: a hip implant can be implanted in the patient only by a surgery team; all components of the surgery team are medical professional and at least one specialized orthopedic surgeon shall be responsible of the surgery
Worked example 2: a thermometer is used by any adult or teenager with normal cognitive and bodily abilities; young children or persons with cognitive impairment may need help in reading and interpreting the results; persons with upper limp handicaps may not be able to handle the device.

data.name: UserRequirementStudy
data.value:
Here you should describe what your end user prefers or needs; this may be the same or different than the patient need and relates more to "easy and friendly to use" that to patient state of health.
Example: describe if the device should be lightweight to be portable; describe the sounds and colors that are expected; describe handling and visual requirements
Worked example 1: a defibrillator for use in airports and other meeting places should be very intuitive to use and should give vocal commands in the language that is common for the end users
Worked example 2: a surgery blade shall have a handle that ensures a safe grip even if it is wet.
